org.nothing
Class JdbcCanBeNice

java.lang.Object
  org.nothing.JdbcCanBeNice

public class JdbcCanBeNice
extends Object

This class mainlty consists of static factory methods that make working with JDBC less painful and more pleasant. Here an example of it's usage : 

 ConnectionProvider connectionProvider = cachingConnectionProvider(driverManagerConnectionProvider(
                "org.apache.derby.jdbc.Driver40",
                "jdbc:derby:crud;create=true", "", ""));
 Number key = doWithConnection(
                sqlTx(
                                sqlUpdate("delete * from table").then(
                                                sqlUpdate("insert into table values(?, ?)",
                                                                true, "a"))).thenReturn(
                                dontThrowSqlException(sqlUpdateAndReturnKey(
                                                "insert into table2 values(?)", 8), -1)),
                connectionProvider);
 RowMapper namesMapper = new RowMapper() {
 
        public String mapRow(ResultSet resultSet, int row)
                        throws SQLException {
                return resultSet.getString("name");
        }
 };
 
 List names = doWithConnection(sqlQuery(
                "select name from table where age < ?", namesMapper, 20),
                connectionProvider);

Author:
Jawher

sqlTx

public static <T> ChainableJdbcAction<T> sqlTx(JdbcAction<T> action)
Wraps a JdbcAction into a transaction. If you need to wrap multiple actions into a single transaction, consider using actions chaining (see ChainableJdbcAction and sqlMakeChainable(JdbcAction)) to group them into a single action and make the latter transactional.

Type Parameters:
T - the return type of the action
Parameters:
action -
Returns:
The result of the wrapped JDBC Action.

sqlUpdate

public static ChainableJdbcAction<Integer> sqlUpdate(String sql,
                                                     Object... params)
A factory method that creates a jdbc update action (update, delete, insert, etc.). Here's how the resulting JdbcAction works :
  • Creates a PreparedStatement
  • Iterates on the parameters calling PreparedStatement.setObject(int, Object) on each of them
  • calls PreparedStatement.executeUpdate()

Parameters:
sql - the sql query, which can use the ? placeholders as with regular JDBC prepared statements
params - the list of the query params, as with regular JDBC prepared statements
Returns:
the number of affected rows

sqlUpdateAndReturnKey

public static ChainableJdbcAction<Number> sqlUpdateAndReturnKey(String sql,
                                                                Object... params)
A factory method that creates a jdbc update action (update, delete, insert, etc.) that returns the generated key. Here's how the resulting JdbcAction works :
  • Creates a PreparedStatement initialized with the parameter Statement.RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS
  • Iterates on the parameters calling PreparedStatement.setObject(int, Object) on each of them
  • calls PreparedStatement.executeUpdate()
  • And finally uses the result set returned by Statement.getGeneratedKeys() to retrieve the generated key
If you need to trieve the query's generated key, please consider using sqlUpdateAndReturnKey(String, Object...).

Parameters:
sql - the sql query, which can use the ? placeholders as with regular JDBC prepared statements
params - the list of the query params, as with regular JDBC prepared statements
Returns:
The generated key

sqlQuery

public static <T> ChainableJdbcAction<List<T>> sqlQuery(String sql,
                                                        RowMapper<T> rowMapper,
                                                        Object... params)
A factory method that creates a jdbc select action. Here's how the resulting JdbcAction works :
  • Creates a PreparedStatement
  • Iterates on the parameters calling PreparedStatement.setObject(int, Object) on each of them
  • calls PreparedStatement.executeQuery()
  • Iterates over the returned result set, calling the method on each iteration and accumulating it's result into a list

Parameters:
sql - the sql query, which can use the ? placeholders as with regular JDBC prepared statements
params - the list of the query params, as with regular JDBC prepared statements
Returns:
A list of entities corresponding to the rows returned by the select query

dontThrowSqlException

public static <T> ChainableJdbcAction<T> dontThrowSqlException(JdbcAction<T> action,
                                                               T resInCasOfException)
Wraps a JdbcAction into an action that catches any thrown SQLException and returns a user supplied value instead of failing.

Type Parameters:
T - the return type of the action
Parameters:
action -
resInCasOfException - the result to return if an SQLException was thrown
Returns:
the wrapped action's result if no SQLException was thrown, resInCasOfException otherwise.
